title: What is an ILS?
content: ILS stands for Instrument Landing System. It's a ground-based system that guides aircraft to the runway.

title: Types of Aircraft
content: From turboprops to jets, learn the main categories and how they operate.

title: Flight Instruments
content: Learn about altimeters, airspeed indicators, and attitude indicators.

title: Air Traffic Control Basics
content: How ATC manages airspace and keeps flights safe.

title: Weather and Aviation
content: Understanding weather patterns that affect flying.

title: Aircraft Lighting Systems
content: Navigation lights, landing lights, strobe lights, and beacon lights all serve important functions for visibility and safety.

title: VOR Navigation
content: VHF Omnidirectional Range is a radio navigation system for guiding aircraft using ground-based stations.

title: Transponders and Squawk Codes
content: Squawk codes help ATC identify aircraft. Common emergency codes: 7500 for hijack, 7600 for radio failure, 7700 for general emergency.

title: Call Signs
content: Aircraft are identified by call signs, which may include airline name and flight number or registration.

title: Holding Patterns
content: Holding patterns are racetrack-shaped loops aircraft fly while waiting for landing clearance.

title: Runway Numbering
content: Runway numbers are based on their magnetic heading, rounded to the nearest 10 degrees.

title: Taxiway Markings
content: Yellow lines and signs guide pilots on taxiways at airports. They help avoid wrong turns or runway incursions.

title: METAR and TAF Reports
content: METARs give current weather at airports, while TAFs are aviation forecasts. Pilots use both to plan flights.

title: Aircraft Engines
content: Jets, turboprops, and piston engines each power different types of aircraft, depending on mission and size.

title: Stall and Spin
content: A stall happens when lift is lost due to too high an angle of attack. A spin is an uncontrolled descent following a stall.

title: Flaps and Slats
content: These extend from the wings to help aircraft take off and land at lower speeds by increasing lift.

title: ATIS Broadcasts
content: Automatic Terminal Information Service gives pilots the latest weather and airport info before they contact ATC.

title: NOTAMs
content: Notice to Air Missions — alerts pilots to hazards or changes at airports or in airspace.

title: Wake Turbulence
content: Larger aircraft generate turbulent air behind them, which can be dangerous for smaller planes following too closely.

title: Jet Streams
content: High-altitude winds that can significantly affect aircraft speed and fuel efficiency depending on direction.

title: Autopilot
content: Autopilot systems help pilots fly the aircraft by automatically controlling heading, altitude, and speed.

title: Ground Effect
content: An increase in lift and decrease in drag when flying very close to the ground, especially during takeoff or landing.

title: Altitude Levels
content: Pilots use pressure altitude and flight levels to maintain vertical separation in high-altitude airspace.

title: Controlled vs. Uncontrolled Airspace
content: Controlled airspace has ATC services, while uncontrolled airspace requires pilots to self-announce and separate.

title: Mayday and Pan-Pan
content: ‘Mayday’ is for emergencies. ‘Pan-Pan’ is for urgent but non-life-threatening issues like system malfunctions.
